The market has slowed from a unit point of view and a utilization point of view, just because of payer pushback requiring additional care before going to surgery, particularly on the lumbar side. Have you seen any softening of the pushback? Has it gotten worse? Any additional color would be great.

No, it's actually been pretty consistent now for the last 6 to 12 months. And while I know we continue to see good performance in our more minimally invasive approach and things that we're doing with both COUGAR and our VIPER systems, overall, if I look at the market, I think the trends have been fairly consistent.
Okay. Thank you, guys.
Next question, please.
Your next question comes from Matt Miksic with Piper Jaffray.

Thanks for taking our questions. One on Ethicon growth, maybe for Alex, just to get a sense of the trends, you talked – we saw some sequential improvements in the U.S. and OUS in the second quarter. You mentioned emerging market suture growth this quarter.

But last quarter, there was this sense of stabilization in the U.S., utilization trends stabilizing. With another quarter under your belt, if you could talk a little bit about how you would characterize the trends here. Is this stabilizing or is it improving? Is it sideways? Alex, any color would be helpful. And then I have a follow-up.
Sure, Matt. Thanks a lot. I would paint it pretty much as sideways, based upon what we have seen so far.
You know, that market usually grows at a pretty consistent 1% to 2% range. We have seen it actually, you know, go negative. It's been relatively flat.

So if I take that and also contrast it and compare it with some of the other data sources that we have around hospital admissions and actual surgical procedures to include ambulatory surgical procedures, I think flat to sideways is probably the best description that I have at this time.
Okay. A follow-up for you also on your comments on emerging markets. You've been in the s1 segments in many of these markets for a while, as you talked about.

Could you talk a little bit about your strategy to penetrate the mid-tier device markets, particularly ortho, spine, trauma in China? Do you expect this to be a two-tiered branding strategy? Is it organic, or it is through some sort of local vehicle? It would be great to get your thoughts on that.
Sure. You know, we are excited about the growth opportunities in China, particularly in the ortho space as we look at not only the s1 and s2 segment.

We have had a strong presence in the s1 for a while, but I was just in China about three weeks ago, opening up a new R&D center we have, and we've really got what I'd say is a several pronged approach to help us, you know, first of all, access new patients, and frankly, provide them and their surgeons a lot better options, and two, to really grow our business.

And it starts with R&D. We recently opened an R&D center there. And our focus there is to, number one, make sure that we have the right insights into the local market needs. And two, to have scientists, engineers, physicians, locally that can work together as part of the team to bring those concepts to life within those markets.

You know, historically, we tended to take our products from the U.S. and the developed markets and take them to China, sometimes at a different price point. But what we would prefer to do is look at things such as in the orthopedic space, is there a need for a different size knee, for a one that is facilitated through easier and more straightforward surgical procedures that can meet the unique needs of that particular market? That's an example of the kinds of things that we're looking at but the same would apply to hips as well as the spine space.
Next, we also have a manufacturing facility in China, and it's really state-of-the-art, and it's something that, you know, we want to be able to continue to build on.

And third, we've also invested significantly in our commercial model. We've got a different organization that focuses on the s2. We think that's really important, and you know, we've seen some positive signs about their accomplishments in the market, but that's also something that we're, you know, spending a lot of time and effort on to make sure that we execute that in the right way.

You know, regarding other partnering opportunities, that's certainly something that we're always looking for. We've got some smaller partnerships already in the region, but we want to continue to build on those as well going forward. That's really our overall approach. Ultimately what we'd like to see is that for us to be able to, you know, develop, design, manufacture products in those markets that may be applicable to emerging markets in other parts of the world outside of China and we're not there today but that would be our goal in the future.

Perfect. Just a clarification on your spine comments a couple of questions ago. You said most of the ortho knee, spine pricing was relatively consistent with q1. Was spine down 5% U.S. not a touch worse than it was in q1 in the U.S.?

If you look only at the U.S. Data, it was a touch worse, but again, if you go back three quarters or so, the data does bounce around. That's why I would just be very cautious about, you know, a single point, and also on a worldwide basis, it's actually been pretty consistent.
Thanks so much.
Next question, please.
Your next question comes from Kristen Stewart with Deutsche Bank.

I have a quick question. I just wanted to make sure I understood you correctly when you were talking about the market growth. I think you had mentioned that you expected the MD&D markets in 2011 to grow slower than 2010, is that correct?
Yes.
Okay, and is that just simply the full-year effect of the slower utilization so your assumptions assume no back half pickup or – by virtue of easier comps?

Remember, last year in 2010, we saw a very strong first half of the year across of most of MD&D so some of that is a lapping affect. Some of it, as I said earlier, we see that the current dynamics that are taking place, particularly in the developed markets, we see those fundamentally continuing through the rest of the year. So there's likely to be some potential upside from just the lapping, but the core underlying dynamics, we think will be the same.
Just on DePuy, what's the ex-Micrus growth number – or decline?
It's basically flat ex-Micrus.

Would you be willing to comment on the decision exit out of Cordis just from a longer-term impact? Obviously, you guys have talked a little bit about 2012 with what the impact of Synthes will be to earnings. Is there any financial impact for Cordis outside of the special charges that we should expect? Is it the decision to exit accretive to numbers, a little bit dilutive?

Kristen, it's Dominic. Just by way of clarity so we didn't exit Cordis, we just exited drug-eluting stents. As you saw, the drug-eluting stents, as Louise mentioned earlier, the total sales in the second quarter were $64 million compared to about $164 million the prior year. So obviously, you know, we going to see as we've exited that DES business, we're going to see less of, you know, quarter-to-quarter, year-over-year drag on the business, and as you know, drug-eluting stent business, when we exclude that from our MD&D overall results over this quarter, the 1% result that MD&D delivered are about 3% excluding the DES change. But other than that and the charges that we've just described earlier in the restructuring charge, there's no other financial impact that you should expect to see.

Kristen, I would add, longer term that we think it's critically important that we always challenge ourselves around our strategic investments for our overall portfolio. And you know, again, while we obviously thought very carefully about this, we think going forward it's the right thing to do, not only for our cardiovascular business but all of MD&D given some of the other, we feel are very exciting opportunities that we have in things such as biosurgicals, energy, EP, and other emerging areas.
You've been pretty active with divestitures. Is there anything else we should be kind of size-wise expecting going forward or do you guys feel the portfolio is pretty good as is?

I won't comment on that right now, but you're right. We've done a number of what I would call smaller divestitures such as our wound care and breast care business in the past. We've done some other small-to-medium size acquisitions, you know, Acclarent, Mentor and others, and you know, we would expect to continue taking that kind of approach going forward.
Thank you.
Next question, please.
Your next question comes from Rick Wise with Leerink Swann.

First question, maybe equally for Dominic and Alex. If you could talk a little bit about and help us think about the second half outlook. European operational growth was 1.9% in the first quarter, 4.5% in the second quarter, stronger than I would have thought. Do you all each, given your different roles, see the second half outlook as stable, worsening given the economic issues. How are you thinking about it? Thank you.

Yeah, it's a great question, Rick. We have some momentum that we're building in the business as you saw, and as I mentioned in the overall comments on guidance, you know there is still this sort of economic climate uncertainty that overhangs the market growth and whether that be European austerity measures and, you know, significant economic price controls across the markets.

So I guess we're cautiously optimistic that the second half of the year will be, you know, just as good as the first year or slightly better, but we are watching it closely because, in fact there are some still uncertain economic times ahead of us, and the actions that countries will take specifically, you know, in the Southern European markets are still unknown as to how they're going to implement their various austerity measures and what impact it could have in the markets we compete in. Alex, anything else?
No. Rick, I completely agree with Dominic's comments.

Okay. Turning last to some more questions on U.S. Consumer, Dominic, down 13% in the first quarter, down 8.5% in the second, when do you get back to neutral to positive growth again? When do we move past this period of declines? Are you hoping it could happen by the fourth quarter or it's going to take longer than that?

I think certainly going into next year as these products in the McNeil consumer business, as I mentioned earlier, start coming online on the shelves and so I said by the first half of the year, the majority of them will be on the shelves, but I think that obviously will be a good comparison to a year just preceding it where we had no such products on the shelves. So that's obviously the major driver.

I think I mentioned earlier and Louise may have mentioned, the business itself, excluding the impact of not having the products on the market, grew at about 2.5% in the second quarter and I think on the same comparison, it was about flat in the first quarter. So obviously, we're seeing some momentum and you see it particularly in skin care and then baby. We're hopeful that the underlying business is continuing to grow and do well in emerging markets. We're really just seeing the impact of not having the products on the shelf, which I think in 2011, as we pointed out, will be behind us. I mean, sorry in 2012, that will be behind us.

Okay and just last quick follow-up on that: when I look at the big pieces and if I'm reading it correctly this quarter, each region, each geographic region, U.S., OUS, in each business showed an accelerated rate of year-over-year growth in the second quarter as compared to the first quarter except OUS consumer. What's going on there?
Let's see, OUS consumer. Let me just get my...
Again, I think I OUS consumer in the first quarter was up 2.6% ex-currency.
It's actually up in the second quarter. It's up 2.8%.
I'm sorry, I take it back, yes. I apologize. I misread my own handwriting. Sorry. Thank you.
You're welcome.

Your next question comes from David Lewis with Morgan Stanley.
Good morning.
Good morning, David.

Dominic, just a quick question. If we go back about a year or two ago, the thought was coming into your significant pharmaceutical pipeline years, I think you thought that spending levels could remain relatively flat and we were going to start to see some nice accretion from the significant pipeline that J&J has versus peers. Just thinking about your comments this morning, maybe you can sort of compare and contrast what I think I heard before versus today. Is it the nature of the competitive environment of pharmaceuticals? Is it just specific spending tied to specific launches? Another way of saying it, do you still believe that you can begin to see significant accretion from the pharmaceutical division as you get into the meat of this pipeline?

Yeah, it's a great question, David. I think this is a matter of timing. You know, obviously, as we launch these products and they ramp up in the marketplace, the effect of having taken the significant cost decisions that we took earlier will have an incremental impact, positive impact to the overall profitability of that business. But of course, as we're launching the products, you know, and products are coming off patent at the same time, you know, do you have a bit of a dilemma because here, look, in the second quarter, LEVAQUIN went off patent and CONCERTA, the authorized generic started. These are significant impacts to the top line.

We're not going to reduce the cost to offset those when at the very same time we're launching all these products and getting ready to launch new products. So I think what you see is just a timing difference. We're going to invest behind the launch of these products, get them out there as best we can. Try to deal with the loss of patent exclusivity of some of the other products like LEVAQUIN and CONCERTA, but then as these products ramp up, I think we should be in great shape in terms of improved profitability.

That's very clear, thanks Dominic. Alex, just a couple of quick questions, I know we're running long. On DePuy, there are a series of external factors facing the entire industry and there have been some internal factors facing DePuy the last three or four quarters, maybe four to six quarters. At this point, are you comfortable that the internal pressures facing DePuy are beginning to ebb and now you're just more focused on what's going to happen in the external environment? So basically, have the internal pressures begun to trough in that segment for you?

Hey, David, that's a good question. I guess the way I would answer that is that I'd step back and provide perhaps a little bit more context on things even like around our hip performance over the last 12 months.

You know, last year in August when we announced the recall of ASR and the first thing that we felt we needed to do is really focus our attention and resources to ensure that patients impacted by the recall got the right information and the right care that they needed in a timely and responsible manner. And while we're obviously concerned about the issues related to ASR, it was important that over the past decade we've had over a million patients that have been helped by a DePuy hip implant and so we remain very committed to this space. We're confident that we're going to be able to recover. So you know, the way that we're looking at it is, you know, first of all, we had to make sure that we looked out after the patients.

Also, we're getting ready to launch several important new products. We've had three 510(k)s and two PMA approvals for new hip products in the last 10-months. These include things like RECLAIM, GRIPTION TF, CoMplete, CERAMAX with AltrX liners and the PINNACLE system and these products were clear approved and we're in the process of launching them literally as I speak. We think it's really important that you give surgeons a lot of options as they consider the right fit for their particular patients. That was first of all.

Second, we're spending a lot of time around surgery, education and awareness. Over the last few years, we have seen the physicians are a little bit more hesitant to travel and learn about new products and techniques. We actually deployed a mobile training institute that's out and it's about an 1,100 square-foot surgeon learning center and this enables DePuy to educate physicians locally without needing to travel. We think that's a unique approach.

Last but certainly not least, just in June, DePuy launched a consumer education awareness campaign called Real Life Tested, and it's designed to really better educate and empower patients around hip and knee replacement surgery and frankly some of the unique options that DePuy offers.

So that's our overall approach. We're confident that over time, you know, we will return to the position that we think we should have in that market, but we realize in the short term, we have to get our proprietary rights.
Thank you very much.
Next, question, please.
your next question comes from Bob Hopkins with Bank of America.
Hi. Thanks for squeezing me in. First question is on Synthes. I was wondering if you guys can just provide an update on when you think you'll be able to announce the financing details?

Hi, Bob, Dominic here. You know, I can't give you a timing. The level of financing alternatives that we are considering have a lot to do with the integration plans that we talked about earlier. So as the integration progresses, we'll combine the businesses in the most efficient manner possible. So we don't really have responses yet from the regulatory authority, so we can't give you an estimate of when we'll be able to announce that, but rest assured that when we – obviously as we close the deal, we'll be able to tell you about it, but as we know more in these updates, we'll provide any information we have when we give you updates periodically throughout the next couple of quarters.

Okay, and Dominic, if you can just elaborate on your comments about financing options as it relates to Synthes, especially when you talk about financing options for equity portion, obviously that equity portion is fixed. So I assume what you're referring to is really just ways to potentially offset the equity dilution via buybacks post-close or other methods over time? You know, any thoughts there would be helpful.

Well, you're exactly right. The form of the transaction, the form of the consideration that Synthes shareholders receive will be exactly as we described it. They will receive shares of J&J stock and cash exactly as we described it, exactly as we negotiated with Synthes, but how we finance that depends on a number of factors and you're exactly right. We may be able to use less overall stock or issue less stock in the aggregate as a result of our ability to finance the re-purchase of our stock as one example. We're looking at a number of alternatives to make it efficient and obviously we have tax considerations here that we're going to make sure we do efficiently.
You still want to continue – the triple-A rating is important to you as it relates to this transaction?

It is. I think maintaining the flexibility that we have as a result of the triple-A rating is still important to us, and I think we can still maintain that flexibility and actually get the transaction to be less dilutive than the conservative estimates we gave earlier.

Great. Really quickly on DePuy, last quarter, you gave some very specific numbers on DePuy's results sequentially from Q4 to Q1 that basically suggested that, you know, pricing was flat sequentially, that units improved sequentially and mix improved sequentially. In other words, you provided some solid evidence that the market felt a little better in the first quarter. So when we think about sequentially on hips and knees here in the second quarter compared to the first quarter, I was wondering if you would be willing to comment on do you think that the market got a little bit worse sequentially as a result of the year-over-year numbers that you showed here, or again, were things stable to up when you look at sequential units and pricing trends?

So Bob, as you know, we're the first one out, so we're just kind of using the crystal ball on the second quarter right now, but for the U.S. hips, we think on a sequential basis, mix price got a little bit more negative and there's been some noise in the market, but until the other manufacturers report, we're not going to have a whole lot of clarity on that. In terms of knees we think price mix sequentially in the U.S. was positive.
Okay.
Primarily mix.
And units?
We've got a slight negative on the market and a whole lot of other factors, but again, until the other manufacturers report, we can't get real clarity on what specifically that is.
Sure, great. I appreciate it, thank you.
Next question, please.
Your next question comes from Rajeev Jashnani with UBS.
Hi, good morning.
Good morning.

My question pertains primarily to the easing comps in the back half of the year as it relates to major joints, and I guess it implies that underlying utilization gets no better than the observed growth rates improve, and I was just wondering if you could quantify what that change may be? For example if a rate of minus one goes to plus one if it's a 1% or 2% improvement or a 2% or 3% improvement just based on the baseline getting a little bit more favorable, and I understand it may not be the same for hips and knees, but any general color would be helpful.

So in general on DePuy, and I'm going from memory, so the first quarter grew about 8% operationally last year. The second quarter grew about 4%, and the third quarter grew about 2%. So you do see the declining, and then I believe the fourth quarter was about 1%. So it kind of halved itself throughout the year. You are going to see easier comps in the DePuy area. Alex has got some more information he can give you.

Right. That was the information for hips and you know, if you look at the knee information. Early in 20120, you were looking at growth rates of, you know, over 10% in Q1, and then on a constant currency basis, let me backup. Q1 is about 10% reported, Q2 around 5%, and then it went down to about 1% in Q3 and Q4, just flat here. So that should give you an idea about those markets.
Okay, last question please, and then Dominic will provide some closing remarks.
Your final question comes from Derrick Sung with Sanford Bernstein.

Hi, thanks for squeezing me in. Dominic, just going back to your guidance comments, I understand kind of the rationale that you are speaking with regard to investing the bottom lines or beats that we have seen here as a result of the tax rate, but if we just focus on the top line here, you have also this quarter, you know, came in above the Street expectations. There's a couple new products on the pharma side that you've launched that presumably were not in your original guidance when you contemplated that. Can you talk about why the top line guidance wouldn't increase and would stay the same?

Right, that's a great question, Derrick. So let me just reiterate. The top line guidance on an operational basis remained the same at between 2.5% and 3.5% growth over the prior year. As you know, second quarter, our growth was 2.6% and in the first quarter, it was 1.8%. So we obviously are expecting in the guidance overall of 2.5% to 3.5% for the year that we will accelerate our growth in the back half of the year, but that was already contemplated in the guidance that we gave.
Okay. So you are saying basically the Street was lower than what you were thinking?

Yeah, I think the Street may have been a little lower than what we actually delivered in the second quarter, but it was pretty much consistent with our overall guidance. Again, we're only at 2.6% for Q2 and 1.8% for Q1. We expect 2.5% to 3.5% for the year. So, we will see the ramp up. We expect to see the ramp up, as you mentioned, of new products that we're launching, but that's already contemplated in the guidance that we have previously given.

Okay, that's helpful. And then on the consumer side of your business, in the U.S., excluding your OTC franchise, there was a nice sort of pickup in almost all of the separate franchises. I'm wondering, how much of that is perhaps a pickup in the overall market and, you know, sort of consumer spending habits, etcetera, or do you feel like all of that is more J&J specific, related to your specific products?

We haven't seen much of a pickup in overall consumer trends. Although in our skin care business, which generally does pretty well despite economic conditions, you know, we've launched lots of new products in the NEUTROGENA line, the NEUTROGENA Naturals, for example, that is getting good uptake by consumers, she AVEENO extension of product lines with AVEENO hair care and the like. So I think we haven't seen much of a change in overall consumer spending habits, but we have seen some very good uptake in the new product launches, particularly NEUTROGENA has really started to come around here and we're glad to see the consumers appreciate the innovation that we're showing in the NEUTROGENA product line.

Okay and just one last one for Alex. Specifically on spine, Alex, can you comment on what impact, if any, you are seeing on the whole BMP controversy as that might relate to overall spinal procedure volumes, perhaps, you know, specific lateral access type procedure volumes? And then also, I guess when you look at your own biologics and bone graft substitute franchise, what impact are you seeing on that with respect to the BMP controversy?
We don't think it's having that significant of an impact at this point.
On procedure volumes or on your own specific biologics?
On us. On us. We think it's certainly having an impact in other areas, but if we're talking about its impact on us, we don't think it's significant.
So some final remarks from Dominic.

Okay, thanks, Louise. In closing, let me just say we're pleased to see the continuing momentum in the second quarter results and we expect to continue to build on our core strengths and with the recent launches and we expect ongoing investments for the second half of the year. We see further opportunity for growth as the global economy stabilizes and our businesses continue addressing the critical unmet healthcare needs of patients and customers.

I do remain confident in our prospects for the year thanks to the dedication, focus and integrity of the people at Johnson & Johnson, and I look forward to speaking with you again in October and updating you on our progress throughout the year. Thanks for your time this morning and have a wonderful day.
thank you. This concludes today's second quarter 2011 earnings conference call.
